natural problem:
Compute the sum
\[\sum_{i = 0}^\infty \sum_{j = 0}^\infty \frac{1}{(i + j + 1)(i + j + 2)(i + j + 3)(i + j + 4)(i + j + 5)(i + j + 6)(i + j + 7)}.\]
natural solution: First, we can write \begin{align} &\frac{1}{(i + j + 1)(i + j + 2) \dotsm (i + j + 6)(i + j + 7)} \\ &= \frac{1}{6} \cdot \frac{(i + j + 7) - (i + j + 1)}{(i + j + 1)(i + j + 2) \dotsm (i + j + 6)(i + j + 7)} \\

&= \frac{1}{6} \left( \frac{1}{(i + j + 1)(i + j + 2) \dotsm (i + j + 6)} - \frac{1}{(i + j + 2) \dotsm (i + j + 6)(i + j + 7)} \right). \end{align}Thus, the following sum telescopes: \begin{align} &\sum_{j = 0}^\infty \frac{1}{(i + j + 1)(i + j + 2) \dotsm (i + j + 6)(i + j + 7)} \\

&= \sum_{j = 0}^\infty \frac{1}{6} \left( \frac{1}{(i + j + 1)(i + j + 2) \dotsm (i + j + 6)} - \frac{1}{(i + j + 2) \dotsm (i + j + 6)(i + j + 7)} \right) \\ &= \frac{1}{6} \left( \frac{1}{(i + 1) \dotsm (i + 6)} - \frac{1}{(i + 2) \dotsm (i + 7)} \right) \\

a_0.formal problem:
theorem
fixes i j :: nat
assumes h0 : "summable (\<lambda>i. summable (\<lambda>j. 1 / ((i + j + 1) * (i + j + 2) * (i + j + 3) * (i + j + 4) * (i + j + 5) * (i + j + 6) * (i + j + 7))))"
shows  "suminf (\<lambda>i. suminf (\<lambda>j. 1 / ((i + j + 1) * (i + j + 2) * (i + j + 3) * (i + j + 4) * (i + j + 5) * (i + j + 6) * (i + j + 7)))) = 1 / 3600"
a_0.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Compute the sum
\[\sum_{i = 0}^\infty \sum_{j = 0}^\infty \frac{1}{(i + j + 1)(i + j + 2)(i + j + 3)(i + j + 4)(i + j + 5)(i + j + 6)(i + j + 7)}.\] The final Answer is \frac{1}{3600}
 ### Proof
 First, we can write \begin{align} &\frac{1}{(i + j + 1)(i + j + 2) \dotsm (i + j + 6)(i + j + 7)} \\ &= \frac{1}{6} \cdot \frac{(i + j + 7) - (i + j + 1)}{(i + j + 1)(i + j + 2) \dotsm (i + j + 6)(i + j + 7)} \\
 &= \frac{1}{6} \left( \frac{1}{(i + j + 1)(i + j + 2) \dotsm (i + j + 6)} - \frac{1}{(i + j + 2) \dotsm (i + j + 6)(i + j + 7)} \right). \end{align}Thus, the following sum telescopes: \begin{align} &\sum_{j = 0}^\infty \frac{1}{(i + j + 1)(i + j + 2) \dotsm (i + j + 6)(i + j + 7)} \\
 &= \sum_{j = 0}^\infty \frac{1}{6} \left( \frac{1}{(i + j + 1)(i + j + 2) \dotsm (i + j + 6)} - \frac{1}{(i + j + 2) \dotsm (i + j + 6)(i + j + 7)} \right) \\ &= \frac{1}{6} \left( \frac{1}{(i + 1) \dotsm (i + 6)} - \frac{1}{(i + 2) \dotsm (i + 7)} \right) \\
 &\quad + \frac{1}{6} \left( \frac{1}{(i + 2) \dotsm (i + 7)} - \frac{1}{(i + 3) \dotsm (i + 8)} \right) \\ &\quad + \frac{1}{6} \left( \frac{1}{(i + 3) \dotsm (i + 8)} - \frac{1}{(i + 4) \dotsm (i + 9)} \right) +\dotsb \\
 &= \frac{1}{6 (i + 1)(i + 2) \dotsm (i + 5)(i + 6)}. \end{align}We can then write \begin{align} &\frac{1}{6 (i + 1)(i + 2) \dotsm (i + 5)(i + 6)} \\ &= \frac{1}{5} \cdot \frac{(i + 6) - (i + 1)}{6 (i + 1)(i + 2) \dotsm (i + 5)(i + 6)} \\
 &= \frac{1}{30} \left( \frac{1}{(i + 1)(i + 2)(i + 3)(i + 4)(i + 5)} - \frac{1}{(i + 2)(i + 3)(i + 4)(i + 5)(i + 6)} \right). \end{align}We obtain another telescoping sum: \begin{align} &\sum_{i = 0}^\infty \frac{1}{6 (i + 1)(i + 2) \dotsm (i + 5)(i + 6)} \\
 &= \sum_{i = 0}^\infty \frac{1}{30} \left( \frac{1}{(i + 1)(i + 2)(i + 3)(i + 4)(i + 5)} - \frac{1}{(i + 2)(i + 3)(i + 4)(i + 5)(i + 6)} \right) \\ &= \frac{1}{30} \left( \frac{1}{(1)(2)(3)(4)(5)} - \frac{1}{(2)(3)(4)(5)(6)} \right) \\
 &\quad + \frac{1}{30} \left( \frac{1}{(2)(3)(4)(5)(6)} - \frac{1}{(3)(4)(5)(6)(7)} \right) \\ &\quad + \frac{1}{30} \left( \frac{1}{(3)(4)(5)(6)(7)} - \frac{1}{(4)(5)(6)(7)(8)} \right) + \dotsb \\ &= \frac{1}{30} \cdot \frac{1}{(1)(2)(3)(4)(5)} = \boxed{\frac{1}{3600}}.
 \end{align}
 *)

theorem
fixes i j :: nat
assumes h0 : "summable (\<lambda>i. summable (\<lambda>j. 1 / ((i + j + 1) * (i + j + 2) * (i + j + 3) * (i + j + 4) * (i + j + 5) * (i + j + 6) * (i + j + 7))))"
shows  "suminf (\<lambda>i. suminf (\<lambda>j. 1 / ((i + j + 1) * (i + j + 2) * (i + j + 3) * (i + j + 4) * (i + j + 5) * (i + j + 6) * (i + j + 7)))) = 1 / 3600"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_0.informal problem: The infinite sum over all natural numbers $i$ and $j$ of the term $\frac{1}{(i + j + 1) * (i + j + 2) * (i + j + 3) * (i + j + 4) * (i + j + 5) * (i + j + 6) * (i + j + 7)}$ is convergent and its sum is $\frac{1}{3600}$.

a_1.formal problem:
theorem
fixes i j :: nat and sum :: "nat \<Rightarrow> nat \<Rightarrow> real"
defines "sum \<equiv> \<lambda>i j. 1 / (real (i + j + 1) * real (i + j + 2) * real (i + j + 3) * real (i + j + 4) * real (i + j + 5) * real (i + j + 6) * real (i + j + 7))"
assumes h0 : "sum = (\<lambda> i j. 1 / ((i + j + 1) * (i + j + 2) * (i + j + 3) * (i + j + 4) * (i + j + 5) * (i + j + 6) * (i + j + 7)))"
shows  "(\<Sum>i. \<Sum>j. sum i j) = 1 / 3600"
a_1.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Compute the sum
\[\sum_{i = 0}^\infty \sum_{j = 0}^\infty \frac{1}{(i + j + 1)(i + j + 2)(i + j + 3)(i + j + 4)(i + j + 5)(i + j + 6)(i + j + 7)}.\] The final Answer is \frac{1}{3600}
 ### Proof
 First, we can write \begin{align} &\frac{1}{(i + j + 1)(i + j + 2) \dotsm (i + j + 6)(i + j + 7)} \\ &= \frac{1}{6} \cdot \frac{(i + j + 7) - (i + j + 1)}{(i + j + 1)(i + j + 2) \dotsm (i + j + 6)(i + j + 7)} \\
 &= \frac{1}{6} \left( \frac{1}{(i + j + 1)(i + j + 2) \dotsm (i + j + 6)} - \frac{1}{(i + j + 2) \dotsm (i + j + 6)(i + j + 7)} \right). \end{align}Thus, the following sum telescopes: \begin{align} &\sum_{j = 0}^\infty \frac{1}{(i + j + 1)(i + j + 2) \dotsm (i + j + 6)(i + j + 7)} \\
 &= \sum_{j = 0}^\infty \frac{1}{6} \left( \frac{1}{(i + j + 1)(i + j + 2) \dotsm (i + j + 6)} - \frac{1}{(i + j + 2) \dotsm (i + j + 6)(i + j + 7)} \right) \\ &= \frac{1}{6} \left( \frac{1}{(i + 1) \dotsm (i + 6)} - \frac{1}{(i + 2) \dotsm (i + 7)} \right) \\
 &\quad + \frac{1}{6} \left( \frac{1}{(i + 2) \dotsm (i + 7)} - \frac{1}{(i + 3) \dotsm (i + 8)} \right) \\ &\quad + \frac{1}{6} \left( \frac{1}{(i + 3) \dotsm (i + 8)} - \frac{1}{(i + 4) \dotsm (i + 9)} \right) +\dotsb \\
 &= \frac{1}{6 (i + 1)(i + 2) \dotsm (i + 5)(i + 6)}. \end{align}We can then write \begin{align} &\frac{1}{6 (i + 1)(i + 2) \dotsm (i + 5)(i + 6)} \\ &= \frac{1}{5} \cdot \frac{(i + 6) - (i + 1)}{6 (i + 1)(i + 2) \dotsm (i + 5)(i + 6)} \\
 &= \frac{1}{30} \left( \frac{1}{(i + 1)(i + 2)(i + 3)(i + 4)(i + 5)} - \frac{1}{(i + 2)(i + 3)(i + 4)(i + 5)(i + 6)} \right). \end{align}We obtain another telescoping sum: \begin{align} &\sum_{i = 0}^\infty \frac{1}{6 (i + 1)(i + 2) \dotsm (i + 5)(i + 6)} \\
 &= \sum_{i = 0}^\infty \frac{1}{30} \left( \frac{1}{(i + 1)(i + 2)(i + 3)(i + 4)(i + 5)} - \frac{1}{(i + 2)(i + 3)(i + 4)(i + 5)(i + 6)} \right) \\ &= \frac{1}{30} \left( \frac{1}{(1)(2)(3)(4)(5)} - \frac{1}{(2)(3)(4)(5)(6)} \right) \\
 &\quad + \frac{1}{30} \left( \frac{1}{(2)(3)(4)(5)(6)} - \frac{1}{(3)(4)(5)(6)(7)} \right) \\ &\quad + \frac{1}{30} \left( \frac{1}{(3)(4)(5)(6)(7)} - \frac{1}{(4)(5)(6)(7)(8)} \right) + \dotsb \\ &= \frac{1}{30} \cdot \frac{1}{(1)(2)(3)(4)(5)} = \boxed{\frac{1}{3600}}.
 \end{align}
 *)

theorem
fixes i j :: nat and sum :: "nat \<Rightarrow> nat \<Rightarrow> real"
defines "sum \<equiv> \<lambda>i j. 1 / (real (i + j + 1) * real (i + j + 2) * real (i + j + 3) * real (i + j + 4) * real (i + j + 5) * real (i + j + 6) * real (i + j + 7))"
assumes h0 : "sum = (\<lambda> i j. 1 / ((i + j + 1) * (i + j + 2) * (i + j + 3) * (i + j + 4) * (i + j + 5) * (i + j + 6) * (i + j + 7)))"
shows  "(\<Sum>i. \<Sum>j. sum i j) = 1 / 3600"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_1.informal problem: Find the sum of the series $\frac{1}{((i + j + 1) * (i + j + 2) * (i + j + 3) * (i + j + 4) * (i + j + 5) * (i + j + 6) * (i + j + 7))}$ for all pairs of natural numbers $(i, j)$. The final answer is $\frac{1}{3600}$.

a_2.formal problem:
theorem
fixes i j :: nat
assumes h0 : "\<forall>i j. (\<Sum>i=0..<\<infinity>. \<Sum>j=0..<\<infinity>. 1 / ((i + j + 1)*(i + j + 2)*(i + j + 3)*(i + j + 4)*(i + j + 5)*(i + j + 6)*(i + j + 7))) = 1 / 3600"
shows  "\<forall>i j. (\<Sum>i=0..<\<infinity>. \<Sum>j=0..<\<infinity>. 1 / ((i + j + 1)*(i + j + 2)*(i + j + 3)*(i + j + 4)*(i + j + 5)*(i + j + 6)*(i + j + 7))) = 1 / 3600"
a_2.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Compute the sum
\[\sum_{i = 0}^\infty \sum_{j = 0}^\infty \frac{1}{(i + j + 1)(i + j + 2)(i + j + 3)(i + j + 4)(i + j + 5)(i + j + 6)(i + j + 7)}.\] The final Answer is \frac{1}{3600}
 ### Proof
 First, we can write \begin{align} &\frac{1}{(i + j + 1)(i + j + 2) \dotsm (i + j + 6)(i + j + 7)} \\ &= \frac{1}{6} \cdot \frac{(i + j + 7) - (i + j + 1)}{(i + j + 1)(i + j + 2) \dotsm (i + j + 6)(i + j + 7)} \\
 &= \frac{1}{6} \left( \frac{1}{(i + j + 1)(i + j + 2) \dotsm (i + j + 6)} - \frac{1}{(i + j + 2) \dotsm (i + j + 6)(i + j + 7)} \right). \end{align}Thus, the following sum telescopes: \begin{align} &\sum_{j = 0}^\infty \frac{1}{(i + j + 1)(i + j + 2) \dotsm (i + j + 6)(i + j + 7)} \\
 &= \sum_{j = 0}^\infty \frac{1}{6} \left( \frac{1}{(i + j + 1)(i + j + 2) \dotsm (i + j + 6)} - \frac{1}{(i + j + 2) \dotsm (i + j + 6)(i + j + 7)} \right) \\ &= \frac{1}{6} \left( \frac{1}{(i + 1) \dotsm (i + 6)} - \frac{1}{(i + 2) \dotsm (i + 7)} \right) \\
 &\quad + \frac{1}{6} \left( \frac{1}{(i + 2) \dotsm (i + 7)} - \frac{1}{(i + 3) \dotsm (i + 8)} \right) \\ &\quad + \frac{1}{6} \left( \frac{1}{(i + 3) \dotsm (i + 8)} - \frac{1}{(i + 4) \dotsm (i + 9)} \right) +\dotsb \\
 &= \frac{1}{6 (i + 1)(i + 2) \dotsm (i + 5)(i + 6)}. \end{align}We can then write \begin{align} &\frac{1}{6 (i + 1)(i + 2) \dotsm (i + 5)(i + 6)} \\ &= \frac{1}{5} \cdot \frac{(i + 6) - (i + 1)}{6 (i + 1)(i + 2) \dotsm (i + 5)(i + 6)} \\
 &= \frac{1}{30} \left( \frac{1}{(i + 1)(i + 2)(i + 3)(i + 4)(i + 5)} - \frac{1}{(i + 2)(i + 3)(i + 4)(i + 5)(i + 6)} \right). \end{align}We obtain another telescoping sum: \begin{align} &\sum_{i = 0}^\infty \frac{1}{6 (i + 1)(i + 2) \dotsm (i + 5)(i + 6)} \\
 &= \sum_{i = 0}^\infty \frac{1}{30} \left( \frac{1}{(i + 1)(i + 2)(i + 3)(i + 4)(i + 5)} - \frac{1}{(i + 2)(i + 3)(i + 4)(i + 5)(i + 6)} \right) \\ &= \frac{1}{30} \left( \frac{1}{(1)(2)(3)(4)(5)} - \frac{1}{(2)(3)(4)(5)(6)} \right) \\
 &\quad + \frac{1}{30} \left( \frac{1}{(2)(3)(4)(5)(6)} - \frac{1}{(3)(4)(5)(6)(7)} \right) \\ &\quad + \frac{1}{30} \left( \frac{1}{(3)(4)(5)(6)(7)} - \frac{1}{(4)(5)(6)(7)(8)} \right) + \dotsb \\ &= \frac{1}{30} \cdot \frac{1}{(1)(2)(3)(4)(5)} = \boxed{\frac{1}{3600}}.
 \end{align}
 *)

theorem
fixes i j :: nat
assumes h0 : "\<forall>i j. (\<Sum>i=0..<\<infinity>. \<Sum>j=0..<\<infinity>. 1 / ((i + j + 1)*(i + j + 2)*(i + j + 3)*(i + j + 4)*(i + j + 5)*(i + j + 6)*(i + j + 7))) = 1 / 3600"
shows  "\<forall>i j. (\<Sum>i=0..<\<infinity>. \<Sum>j=0..<\<infinity>. 1 / ((i + j + 1)*(i + j + 2)*(i + j + 3)*(i + j + 4)*(i + j + 5)*(i + j + 6)*(i + j + 7))) = 1 / 3600"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_2.informal problem: For every pair of natural numbers i and j, the sum over all i from 0 to infinity, and for each i, the sum over all j from 0 to infinity, of the reciprocal of the product of 7 consecutive numbers starting from i + j + 1, is equal to 1/3600. Is this always true?

a_3.formal problem:
theorem
fixes s :: "(nat \<Rightarrow> nat \<Rightarrow> real) \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "\<forall>i j. s i j = 1 / ((i + j + 1) * (i + j + 2) * (i + j + 3) * (i + j + 4) * (i + j + 5) * (i + j + 6) * (i + j + 7))"
and h1 : "summable (\<lambda>i. summable (\<lambda>j. s i j))"
shows  "suminf (\<lambda>i. suminf (\<lambda>j. s i j)) = 1 / 3600"
a_3.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Compute the sum
\[\sum_{i = 0}^\infty \sum_{j = 0}^\infty \frac{1}{(i + j + 1)(i + j + 2)(i + j + 3)(i + j + 4)(i + j + 5)(i + j + 6)(i + j + 7)}.\] The final Answer is \frac{1}{3600}
 ### Proof
 First, we can write \begin{align} &\frac{1}{(i + j + 1)(i + j + 2) \dotsm (i + j + 6)(i + j + 7)} \\ &= \frac{1}{6} \cdot \frac{(i + j + 7) - (i + j + 1)}{(i + j + 1)(i + j + 2) \dotsm (i + j + 6)(i + j + 7)} \\
 &= \frac{1}{6} \left( \frac{1}{(i + j + 1)(i + j + 2) \dotsm (i + j + 6)} - \frac{1}{(i + j + 2) \dotsm (i + j + 6)(i + j + 7)} \right). \end{align}Thus, the following sum telescopes: \begin{align} &\sum_{j = 0}^\infty \frac{1}{(i + j + 1)(i + j + 2) \dotsm (i + j + 6)(i + j + 7)} \\
 &= \sum_{j = 0}^\infty \frac{1}{6} \left( \frac{1}{(i + j + 1)(i + j + 2) \dotsm (i + j + 6)} - \frac{1}{(i + j + 2) \dotsm (i + j + 6)(i + j + 7)} \right) \\ &= \frac{1}{6} \left( \frac{1}{(i + 1) \dotsm (i + 6)} - \frac{1}{(i + 2) \dotsm (i + 7)} \right) \\
 &\quad + \frac{1}{6} \left( \frac{1}{(i + 2) \dotsm (i + 7)} - \frac{1}{(i + 3) \dotsm (i + 8)} \right) \\ &\quad + \frac{1}{6} \left( \frac{1}{(i + 3) \dotsm (i + 8)} - \frac{1}{(i + 4) \dotsm (i + 9)} \right) +\dotsb \\
 &= \frac{1}{6 (i + 1)(i + 2) \dotsm (i + 5)(i + 6)}. \end{align}We can then write \begin{align} &\frac{1}{6 (i + 1)(i + 2) \dotsm (i + 5)(i + 6)} \\ &= \frac{1}{5} \cdot \frac{(i + 6) - (i + 1)}{6 (i + 1)(i + 2) \dotsm (i + 5)(i + 6)} \\
 &= \frac{1}{30} \left( \frac{1}{(i + 1)(i + 2)(i + 3)(i + 4)(i + 5)} - \frac{1}{(i + 2)(i + 3)(i + 4)(i + 5)(i + 6)} \right). \end{align}We obtain another telescoping sum: \begin{align} &\sum_{i = 0}^\infty \frac{1}{6 (i + 1)(i + 2) \dotsm (i + 5)(i + 6)} \\
 &= \sum_{i = 0}^\infty \frac{1}{30} \left( \frac{1}{(i + 1)(i + 2)(i + 3)(i + 4)(i + 5)} - \frac{1}{(i + 2)(i + 3)(i + 4)(i + 5)(i + 6)} \right) \\ &= \frac{1}{30} \left( \frac{1}{(1)(2)(3)(4)(5)} - \frac{1}{(2)(3)(4)(5)(6)} \right) \\
 &\quad + \frac{1}{30} \left( \frac{1}{(2)(3)(4)(5)(6)} - \frac{1}{(3)(4)(5)(6)(7)} \right) \\ &\quad + \frac{1}{30} \left( \frac{1}{(3)(4)(5)(6)(7)} - \frac{1}{(4)(5)(6)(7)(8)} \right) + \dotsb \\ &= \frac{1}{30} \cdot \frac{1}{(1)(2)(3)(4)(5)} = \boxed{\frac{1}{3600}}.
 \end{align}
 *)

theorem
fixes s :: "(nat \<Rightarrow> nat \<Rightarrow> real) \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "\<forall>i j. s i j = 1 / ((i + j + 1) * (i + j + 2) * (i + j + 3) * (i + j + 4) * (i + j + 5) * (i + j + 6) * (i + j + 7))"
and h1 : "summable (\<lambda>i. summable (\<lambda>j. s i j))"
shows  "suminf (\<lambda>i. suminf (\<lambda>j. s i j)) = 1 / 3600"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_3.informal problem: Suppose $s(i,j) = \frac{1}{(i + j + 1) (i + j + 2) (i + j + 3) (i + j + 4) (i + j + 5) (i + j + 6) (i + j + 7)}$ for all natural numbers $i$ and $j$. If the double series $\sum\limits_{i=0}^{\infty} \sum\limits_{j=0}^{\infty} s(i, j)$ is convergent, what is the sum of the series? The final answer is $\frac{1}{3600}$.

a_4.formal problem:
theorem
fixes i j :: nat
assumes h0 : "summable (\<lambda>i. summable (\<lambda>j. 1 / ((i + j + 1) * (i + j + 2) * (i + j + 3) * (i + j + 4) * (i + j + 5) * (i + j + 6) * (i + j + 7))))"
shows  "suminf (\<lambda>i. suminf (\<lambda>j. 1 / ((i + j + 1) * (i + j + 2) * (i + j + 3) * (i + j + 4) * (i + j + 5) * (i + j + 6) * (i + j + 7)))) = 1 / 3600"
a_4.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Compute the sum
\[\sum_{i = 0}^\infty \sum_{j = 0}^\infty \frac{1}{(i + j + 1)(i + j + 2)(i + j + 3)(i + j + 4)(i + j + 5)(i + j + 6)(i + j + 7)}.\] The final Answer is \frac{1}{3600}
 ### Proof
 First, we can write \begin{align} &\frac{1}{(i + j + 1)(i + j + 2) \dotsm (i + j + 6)(i + j + 7)} \\ &= \frac{1}{6} \cdot \frac{(i + j + 7) - (i + j + 1)}{(i + j + 1)(i + j + 2) \dotsm (i + j + 6)(i + j + 7)} \\
 &= \frac{1}{6} \left( \frac{1}{(i + j + 1)(i + j + 2) \dotsm (i + j + 6)} - \frac{1}{(i + j + 2) \dotsm (i + j + 6)(i + j + 7)} \right). \end{align}Thus, the following sum telescopes: \begin{align} &\sum_{j = 0}^\infty \frac{1}{(i + j + 1)(i + j + 2) \dotsm (i + j + 6)(i + j + 7)} \\
 &= \sum_{j = 0}^\infty \frac{1}{6} \left( \frac{1}{(i + j + 1)(i + j + 2) \dotsm (i + j + 6)} - \frac{1}{(i + j + 2) \dotsm (i + j + 6)(i + j + 7)} \right) \\ &= \frac{1}{6} \left( \frac{1}{(i + 1) \dotsm (i + 6)} - \frac{1}{(i + 2) \dotsm (i + 7)} \right) \\
 &\quad + \frac{1}{6} \left( \frac{1}{(i + 2) \dotsm (i + 7)} - \frac{1}{(i + 3) \dotsm (i + 8)} \right) \\ &\quad + \frac{1}{6} \left( \frac{1}{(i + 3) \dotsm (i + 8)} - \frac{1}{(i + 4) \dotsm (i + 9)} \right) +\dotsb \\
 &= \frac{1}{6 (i + 1)(i + 2) \dotsm (i + 5)(i + 6)}. \end{align}We can then write \begin{align} &\frac{1}{6 (i + 1)(i + 2) \dotsm (i + 5)(i + 6)} \\ &= \frac{1}{5} \cdot \frac{(i + 6) - (i + 1)}{6 (i + 1)(i + 2) \dotsm (i + 5)(i + 6)} \\
 &= \frac{1}{30} \left( \frac{1}{(i + 1)(i + 2)(i + 3)(i + 4)(i + 5)} - \frac{1}{(i + 2)(i + 3)(i + 4)(i + 5)(i + 6)} \right). \end{align}We obtain another telescoping sum: \begin{align} &\sum_{i = 0}^\infty \frac{1}{6 (i + 1)(i + 2) \dotsm (i + 5)(i + 6)} \\
 &= \sum_{i = 0}^\infty \frac{1}{30} \left( \frac{1}{(i + 1)(i + 2)(i + 3)(i + 4)(i + 5)} - \frac{1}{(i + 2)(i + 3)(i + 4)(i + 5)(i + 6)} \right) \\ &= \frac{1}{30} \left( \frac{1}{(1)(2)(3)(4)(5)} - \frac{1}{(2)(3)(4)(5)(6)} \right) \\
 &\quad + \frac{1}{30} \left( \frac{1}{(2)(3)(4)(5)(6)} - \frac{1}{(3)(4)(5)(6)(7)} \right) \\ &\quad + \frac{1}{30} \left( \frac{1}{(3)(4)(5)(6)(7)} - \frac{1}{(4)(5)(6)(7)(8)} \right) + \dotsb \\ &= \frac{1}{30} \cdot \frac{1}{(1)(2)(3)(4)(5)} = \boxed{\frac{1}{3600}}.
 \end{align}
 *)

theorem
fixes i j :: nat
assumes h0 : "summable (\<lambda>i. summable (\<lambda>j. 1 / ((i + j + 1) * (i + j + 2) * (i + j + 3) * (i + j + 4) * (i + j + 5) * (i + j + 6) * (i + j + 7))))"
shows  "suminf (\<lambda>i. suminf (\<lambda>j. 1 / ((i + j + 1) * (i + j + 2) * (i + j + 3) * (i + j + 4) * (i + j + 5) * (i + j + 6) * (i + j + 7)))) = 1 / 3600"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_4.informal problem: Consider an infinite series where each term is a nested infinite series. The terms of the nested series are given by $1 / ((i + j + 1) * (i + j + 2) * (i + j + 3) * (i + j + 4) * (i + j + 5) * (i + j + 6) * (i + j + 7))$ for natural numbers i and j. If this entire series is summable, calculate the sum of all terms in the series. The final answer is $1 / 3600$.

a_5.formal problem:
theorem
fixes sum :: "nat \<Rightarrow> nat \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "\<forall>i j. sum i j = 1 / ((i + j + 1) * (i + j + 2) * (i + j + 3) * (i + j + 4) * (i + j + 5) * (i + j + 6) * (i + j + 7))"
shows  "(\<Sum>i\<in>UNIV. \<Sum>j\<in>UNIV. sum i j) = 1 / 3600"
a_5.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Compute the sum
\[\sum_{i = 0}^\infty \sum_{j = 0}^\infty \frac{1}{(i + j + 1)(i + j + 2)(i + j + 3)(i + j + 4)(i + j + 5)(i + j + 6)(i + j + 7)}.\] The final Answer is \frac{1}{3600}
 ### Proof
 First, we can write \begin{align} &\frac{1}{(i + j + 1)(i + j + 2) \dotsm (i + j + 6)(i + j + 7)} \\ &= \frac{1}{6} \cdot \frac{(i + j + 7) - (i + j + 1)}{(i + j + 1)(i + j + 2) \dotsm (i + j + 6)(i + j + 7)} \\
 &= \frac{1}{6} \left( \frac{1}{(i + j + 1)(i + j + 2) \dotsm (i + j + 6)} - \frac{1}{(i + j + 2) \dotsm (i + j + 6)(i + j + 7)} \right). \end{align}Thus, the following sum telescopes: \begin{align} &\sum_{j = 0}^\infty \frac{1}{(i + j + 1)(i + j + 2) \dotsm (i + j + 6)(i + j + 7)} \\
 &= \sum_{j = 0}^\infty \frac{1}{6} \left( \frac{1}{(i + j + 1)(i + j + 2) \dotsm (i + j + 6)} - \frac{1}{(i + j + 2) \dotsm (i + j + 6)(i + j + 7)} \right) \\ &= \frac{1}{6} \left( \frac{1}{(i + 1) \dotsm (i + 6)} - \frac{1}{(i + 2) \dotsm (i + 7)} \right) \\
 &\quad + \frac{1}{6} \left( \frac{1}{(i + 2) \dotsm (i + 7)} - \frac{1}{(i + 3) \dotsm (i + 8)} \right) \\ &\quad + \frac{1}{6} \left( \frac{1}{(i + 3) \dotsm (i + 8)} - \frac{1}{(i + 4) \dotsm (i + 9)} \right) +\dotsb \\
 &= \frac{1}{6 (i + 1)(i + 2) \dotsm (i + 5)(i + 6)}. \end{align}We can then write \begin{align} &\frac{1}{6 (i + 1)(i + 2) \dotsm (i + 5)(i + 6)} \\ &= \frac{1}{5} \cdot \frac{(i + 6) - (i + 1)}{6 (i + 1)(i + 2) \dotsm (i + 5)(i + 6)} \\
 &= \frac{1}{30} \left( \frac{1}{(i + 1)(i + 2)(i + 3)(i + 4)(i + 5)} - \frac{1}{(i + 2)(i + 3)(i + 4)(i + 5)(i + 6)} \right). \end{align}We obtain another telescoping sum: \begin{align} &\sum_{i = 0}^\infty \frac{1}{6 (i + 1)(i + 2) \dotsm (i + 5)(i + 6)} \\
 &= \sum_{i = 0}^\infty \frac{1}{30} \left( \frac{1}{(i + 1)(i + 2)(i + 3)(i + 4)(i + 5)} - \frac{1}{(i + 2)(i + 3)(i + 4)(i + 5)(i + 6)} \right) \\ &= \frac{1}{30} \left( \frac{1}{(1)(2)(3)(4)(5)} - \frac{1}{(2)(3)(4)(5)(6)} \right) \\
 &\quad + \frac{1}{30} \left( \frac{1}{(2)(3)(4)(5)(6)} - \frac{1}{(3)(4)(5)(6)(7)} \right) \\ &\quad + \frac{1}{30} \left( \frac{1}{(3)(4)(5)(6)(7)} - \frac{1}{(4)(5)(6)(7)(8)} \right) + \dotsb \\ &= \frac{1}{30} \cdot \frac{1}{(1)(2)(3)(4)(5)} = \boxed{\frac{1}{3600}}.
 \end{align}
 *)

theorem
fixes sum :: "nat \<Rightarrow> nat \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "\<forall>i j. sum i j = 1 / ((i + j + 1) * (i + j + 2) * (i + j + 3) * (i + j + 4) * (i + j + 5) * (i + j + 6) * (i + j + 7))"
shows  "(\<Sum>i\<in>UNIV. \<Sum>j\<in>UNIV. sum i j) = 1 / 3600"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_5.informal problem: Calculate the sum over all natural numbers $i$ and $j$ of $\frac{1}{(i+j+1)(i+j+2)(i+j+3)(i+j+4)(i+j+5)(i+j+6)(i+j+7)}$. The final result is $\frac{1}{3600}$.

a_6.formal problem:
theorem
fixes i j :: nat
assumes h0 : "\<forall> i j. ((1 / ((i + j + 1) * (i + j + 2) * (i + j + 3) * (i + j + 4) * (i + j + 5) * (i + j + 6) * (i + j + 7))) sums (\<lambda>n. sum (\<lambda>k. 1 / ((n + k + 1) * (n + k + 2) * (n + k + 3) * (n + k + 4) * (n + k + 5) * (n + k + 6) * (n + k + 7))) {..n})) at_top"
shows  "(\<lambda>n. sum (\<lambda>k. 1 / ((n + k + 1) * (n + k + 2) * (n + k + 3) * (n + k + 4) * (n + k + 5) * (n + k + 6) * (n + k + 7))) {..n}) sums (1 / 3600)"
a_6.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Compute the sum
\[\sum_{i = 0}^\infty \sum_{j = 0}^\infty \frac{1}{(i + j + 1)(i + j + 2)(i + j + 3)(i + j + 4)(i + j + 5)(i + j + 6)(i + j + 7)}.\] The final Answer is \frac{1}{3600}
 ### Proof
 First, we can write \begin{align} &\frac{1}{(i + j + 1)(i + j + 2) \dotsm (i + j + 6)(i + j + 7)} \\ &= \frac{1}{6} \cdot \frac{(i + j + 7) - (i + j + 1)}{(i + j + 1)(i + j + 2) \dotsm (i + j + 6)(i + j + 7)} \\
 &= \frac{1}{6} \left( \frac{1}{(i + j + 1)(i + j + 2) \dotsm (i + j + 6)} - \frac{1}{(i + j + 2) \dotsm (i + j + 6)(i + j + 7)} \right). \end{align}Thus, the following sum telescopes: \begin{align} &\sum_{j = 0}^\infty \frac{1}{(i + j + 1)(i + j + 2) \dotsm (i + j + 6)(i + j + 7)} \\
 &= \sum_{j = 0}^\infty \frac{1}{6} \left( \frac{1}{(i + j + 1)(i + j + 2) \dotsm (i + j + 6)} - \frac{1}{(i + j + 2) \dotsm (i + j + 6)(i + j + 7)} \right) \\ &= \frac{1}{6} \left( \frac{1}{(i + 1) \dotsm (i + 6)} - \frac{1}{(i + 2) \dotsm (i + 7)} \right) \\
 &\quad + \frac{1}{6} \left( \frac{1}{(i + 2) \dotsm (i + 7)} - \frac{1}{(i + 3) \dotsm (i + 8)} \right) \\ &\quad + \frac{1}{6} \left( \frac{1}{(i + 3) \dotsm (i + 8)} - \frac{1}{(i + 4) \dotsm (i + 9)} \right) +\dotsb \\
 &= \frac{1}{6 (i + 1)(i + 2) \dotsm (i + 5)(i + 6)}. \end{align}We can then write \begin{align} &\frac{1}{6 (i + 1)(i + 2) \dotsm (i + 5)(i + 6)} \\ &= \frac{1}{5} \cdot \frac{(i + 6) - (i + 1)}{6 (i + 1)(i + 2) \dotsm (i + 5)(i + 6)} \\
 &= \frac{1}{30} \left( \frac{1}{(i + 1)(i + 2)(i + 3)(i + 4)(i + 5)} - \frac{1}{(i + 2)(i + 3)(i + 4)(i + 5)(i + 6)} \right). \end{align}We obtain another telescoping sum: \begin{align} &\sum_{i = 0}^\infty \frac{1}{6 (i + 1)(i + 2) \dotsm (i + 5)(i + 6)} \\
 &= \sum_{i = 0}^\infty \frac{1}{30} \left( \frac{1}{(i + 1)(i + 2)(i + 3)(i + 4)(i + 5)} - \frac{1}{(i + 2)(i + 3)(i + 4)(i + 5)(i + 6)} \right) \\ &= \frac{1}{30} \left( \frac{1}{(1)(2)(3)(4)(5)} - \frac{1}{(2)(3)(4)(5)(6)} \right) \\
 &\quad + \frac{1}{30} \left( \frac{1}{(2)(3)(4)(5)(6)} - \frac{1}{(3)(4)(5)(6)(7)} \right) \\ &\quad + \frac{1}{30} \left( \frac{1}{(3)(4)(5)(6)(7)} - \frac{1}{(4)(5)(6)(7)(8)} \right) + \dotsb \\ &= \frac{1}{30} \cdot \frac{1}{(1)(2)(3)(4)(5)} = \boxed{\frac{1}{3600}}.
 \end{align}
 *)

theorem
fixes i j :: nat
assumes h0 : "\<forall> i j. ((1 / ((i + j + 1) * (i + j + 2) * (i + j + 3) * (i + j + 4) * (i + j + 5) * (i + j + 6) * (i + j + 7))) sums (\<lambda>n. sum (\<lambda>k. 1 / ((n + k + 1) * (n + k + 2) * (n + k + 3) * (n + k + 4) * (n + k + 5) * (n + k + 6) * (n + k + 7))) {..n})) at_top"
shows  "(\<lambda>n. sum (\<lambda>k. 1 / ((n + k + 1) * (n + k + 2) * (n + k + 3) * (n + k + 4) * (n + k + 5) * (n + k + 6) * (n + k + 7))) {..n}) sums (1 / 3600)"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_6.informal problem: Let us define a function that, for any two natural numbers $i$ and $j$, gives the reciprocal of the product of the following seven terms: $(i+j+1)$, $(i+j+2)$, $(i+j+3)$, $(i+j+4)$, $(i+j+5)$, $(i+j+6)$, and $(i+j+7)$. The theorem proves that if you sum up the values of this function over all possible pairs of natural numbers $(i, j)$, the series converges to $\frac{1}{3600}$.

a_7.formal problem:
theorem
fixes sum :: "nat \<Rightarrow> nat \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> i j. sum i j = 1 / ((i + j + 1) * (i + j + 2) * (i + j + 3) * (i + j + 4) * (i + j + 5) * (i + j + 6) * (i + j + 7))"
shows  "suminf (\<lambda> i. suminf (\<lambda> j. sum i j)) = 1 / 3600"
a_7.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Compute the sum
\[\sum_{i = 0}^\infty \sum_{j = 0}^\infty \frac{1}{(i + j + 1)(i + j + 2)(i + j + 3)(i + j + 4)(i + j + 5)(i + j + 6)(i + j + 7)}.\] The final Answer is \frac{1}{3600}
 ### Proof
 First, we can write \begin{align} &\frac{1}{(i + j + 1)(i + j + 2) \dotsm (i + j + 6)(i + j + 7)} \\ &= \frac{1}{6} \cdot \frac{(i + j + 7) - (i + j + 1)}{(i + j + 1)(i + j + 2) \dotsm (i + j + 6)(i + j + 7)} \\
 &= \frac{1}{6} \left( \frac{1}{(i + j + 1)(i + j + 2) \dotsm (i + j + 6)} - \frac{1}{(i + j + 2) \dotsm (i + j + 6)(i + j + 7)} \right). \end{align}Thus, the following sum telescopes: \begin{align} &\sum_{j = 0}^\infty \frac{1}{(i + j + 1)(i + j + 2) \dotsm (i + j + 6)(i + j + 7)} \\
 &= \sum_{j = 0}^\infty \frac{1}{6} \left( \frac{1}{(i + j + 1)(i + j + 2) \dotsm (i + j + 6)} - \frac{1}{(i + j + 2) \dotsm (i + j + 6)(i + j + 7)} \right) \\ &= \frac{1}{6} \left( \frac{1}{(i + 1) \dotsm (i + 6)} - \frac{1}{(i + 2) \dotsm (i + 7)} \right) \\
 &\quad + \frac{1}{6} \left( \frac{1}{(i + 2) \dotsm (i + 7)} - \frac{1}{(i + 3) \dotsm (i + 8)} \right) \\ &\quad + \frac{1}{6} \left( \frac{1}{(i + 3) \dotsm (i + 8)} - \frac{1}{(i + 4) \dotsm (i + 9)} \right) +\dotsb \\
 &= \frac{1}{6 (i + 1)(i + 2) \dotsm (i + 5)(i + 6)}. \end{align}We can then write \begin{align} &\frac{1}{6 (i + 1)(i + 2) \dotsm (i + 5)(i + 6)} \\ &= \frac{1}{5} \cdot \frac{(i + 6) - (i + 1)}{6 (i + 1)(i + 2) \dotsm (i + 5)(i + 6)} \\
 &= \frac{1}{30} \left( \frac{1}{(i + 1)(i + 2)(i + 3)(i + 4)(i + 5)} - \frac{1}{(i + 2)(i + 3)(i + 4)(i + 5)(i + 6)} \right). \end{align}We obtain another telescoping sum: \begin{align} &\sum_{i = 0}^\infty \frac{1}{6 (i + 1)(i + 2) \dotsm (i + 5)(i + 6)} \\
 &= \sum_{i = 0}^\infty \frac{1}{30} \left( \frac{1}{(i + 1)(i + 2)(i + 3)(i + 4)(i + 5)} - \frac{1}{(i + 2)(i + 3)(i + 4)(i + 5)(i + 6)} \right) \\ &= \frac{1}{30} \left( \frac{1}{(1)(2)(3)(4)(5)} - \frac{1}{(2)(3)(4)(5)(6)} \right) \\
 &\quad + \frac{1}{30} \left( \frac{1}{(2)(3)(4)(5)(6)} - \frac{1}{(3)(4)(5)(6)(7)} \right) \\ &\quad + \frac{1}{30} \left( \frac{1}{(3)(4)(5)(6)(7)} - \frac{1}{(4)(5)(6)(7)(8)} \right) + \dotsb \\ &= \frac{1}{30} \cdot \frac{1}{(1)(2)(3)(4)(5)} = \boxed{\frac{1}{3600}}.
 \end{align}
 *)

theorem
fixes sum :: "nat \<Rightarrow> nat \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> i j. sum i j = 1 / ((i + j + 1) * (i + j + 2) * (i + j + 3) * (i + j + 4) * (i + j + 5) * (i + j + 6) * (i + j + 7))"
shows  "suminf (\<lambda> i. suminf (\<lambda> j. sum i j)) = 1 / 3600"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_7.informal problem: Find the sum of an infinite series where each term is $\frac{1}{(i + j + 1) * (i + j + 2) * (i + j + 3) * (i + j + 4) * (i + j + 5) * (i + j + 6) * (i + j + 7)}$, with $i$ and $j$ ranging over all natural numbers. The final answer is $\frac{1}{3600}$.

a_8.formal problem:
theorem
fixes f :: "nat \<Rightarrow> nat \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "\<forall>i j. f i j = 1 / ((i + j + 1) * (i + j + 2) * (i + j + 3) * (i + j + 4) * (i + j + 5) * (i + j + 6) * (i + j + 7))"
shows  "suminf (\<lambda>i. suminf (f i)) = 1 / 3600"
a_8.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Compute the sum
\[\sum_{i = 0}^\infty \sum_{j = 0}^\infty \frac{1}{(i + j + 1)(i + j + 2)(i + j + 3)(i + j + 4)(i + j + 5)(i + j + 6)(i + j + 7)}.\] The final Answer is \frac{1}{3600}
 ### Proof
 First, we can write \begin{align} &\frac{1}{(i + j + 1)(i + j + 2) \dotsm (i + j + 6)(i + j + 7)} \\ &= \frac{1}{6} \cdot \frac{(i + j + 7) - (i + j + 1)}{(i + j + 1)(i + j + 2) \dotsm (i + j + 6)(i + j + 7)} \\
 &= \frac{1}{6} \left( \frac{1}{(i + j + 1)(i + j + 2) \dotsm (i + j + 6)} - \frac{1}{(i + j + 2) \dotsm (i + j + 6)(i + j + 7)} \right). \end{align}Thus, the following sum telescopes: \begin{align} &\sum_{j = 0}^\infty \frac{1}{(i + j + 1)(i + j + 2) \dotsm (i + j + 6)(i + j + 7)} \\
 &= \sum_{j = 0}^\infty \frac{1}{6} \left( \frac{1}{(i + j + 1)(i + j + 2) \dotsm (i + j + 6)} - \frac{1}{(i + j + 2) \dotsm (i + j + 6)(i + j + 7)} \right) \\ &= \frac{1}{6} \left( \frac{1}{(i + 1) \dotsm (i + 6)} - \frac{1}{(i + 2) \dotsm (i + 7)} \right) \\
 &\quad + \frac{1}{6} \left( \frac{1}{(i + 2) \dotsm (i + 7)} - \frac{1}{(i + 3) \dotsm (i + 8)} \right) \\ &\quad + \frac{1}{6} \left( \frac{1}{(i + 3) \dotsm (i + 8)} - \frac{1}{(i + 4) \dotsm (i + 9)} \right) +\dotsb \\
 &= \frac{1}{6 (i + 1)(i + 2) \dotsm (i + 5)(i + 6)}. \end{align}We can then write \begin{align} &\frac{1}{6 (i + 1)(i + 2) \dotsm (i + 5)(i + 6)} \\ &= \frac{1}{5} \cdot \frac{(i + 6) - (i + 1)}{6 (i + 1)(i + 2) \dotsm (i + 5)(i + 6)} \\
 &= \frac{1}{30} \left( \frac{1}{(i + 1)(i + 2)(i + 3)(i + 4)(i + 5)} - \frac{1}{(i + 2)(i + 3)(i + 4)(i + 5)(i + 6)} \right). \end{align}We obtain another telescoping sum: \begin{align} &\sum_{i = 0}^\infty \frac{1}{6 (i + 1)(i + 2) \dotsm (i + 5)(i + 6)} \\
 &= \sum_{i = 0}^\infty \frac{1}{30} \left( \frac{1}{(i + 1)(i + 2)(i + 3)(i + 4)(i + 5)} - \frac{1}{(i + 2)(i + 3)(i + 4)(i + 5)(i + 6)} \right) \\ &= \frac{1}{30} \left( \frac{1}{(1)(2)(3)(4)(5)} - \frac{1}{(2)(3)(4)(5)(6)} \right) \\
 &\quad + \frac{1}{30} \left( \frac{1}{(2)(3)(4)(5)(6)} - \frac{1}{(3)(4)(5)(6)(7)} \right) \\ &\quad + \frac{1}{30} \left( \frac{1}{(3)(4)(5)(6)(7)} - \frac{1}{(4)(5)(6)(7)(8)} \right) + \dotsb \\ &= \frac{1}{30} \cdot \frac{1}{(1)(2)(3)(4)(5)} = \boxed{\frac{1}{3600}}.
 \end{align}
 *)

theorem
fixes f :: "nat \<Rightarrow> nat \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "\<forall>i j. f i j = 1 / ((i + j + 1) * (i + j + 2) * (i + j + 3) * (i + j + 4) * (i + j + 5) * (i + j + 6) * (i + j + 7))"
shows  "suminf (\<lambda>i. suminf (f i)) = 1 / 3600"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_8.informal problem: A function $f$ is defined such that for all natural numbers $i$ and $j$, $f(i,j) = \frac{1}{(i+j+1)(i+j+2)(i+j+3)(i+j+4)(i+j+5)(i+j+6)(i+j+7)}$. What is the sum of all possible values of $f(i,j)$ as $i$ and $j$ each vary over all natural numbers? The answer is $\frac{1}{3600}$.

a_9.formal problem:
theorem
fixes sum :: "nat \<Rightarrow> nat \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "\<forall>i j. sum i j = 1 / ((i + j + 1)*(i + j + 2)*(i + j + 3)*(i + j + 4)*(i + j + 5)*(i + j + 6)*(i + j + 7))"
and h1 : "\<forall>i. (\<Sum>j. sum i j) = 1 / 3600"
shows  "(\<Sum>i. \<Sum>j. sum i j) = 1 / 3600"
a_9.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Compute the sum
\[\sum_{i = 0}^\infty \sum_{j = 0}^\infty \frac{1}{(i + j + 1)(i + j + 2)(i + j + 3)(i + j + 4)(i + j + 5)(i + j + 6)(i + j + 7)}.\] The final Answer is \frac{1}{3600}
 ### Proof
 First, we can write \begin{align} &\frac{1}{(i + j + 1)(i + j + 2) \dotsm (i + j + 6)(i + j + 7)} \\ &= \frac{1}{6} \cdot \frac{(i + j + 7) - (i + j + 1)}{(i + j + 1)(i + j + 2) \dotsm (i + j + 6)(i + j + 7)} \\
 &= \frac{1}{6} \left( \frac{1}{(i + j + 1)(i + j + 2) \dotsm (i + j + 6)} - \frac{1}{(i + j + 2) \dotsm (i + j + 6)(i + j + 7)} \right). \end{align}Thus, the following sum telescopes: \begin{align} &\sum_{j = 0}^\infty \frac{1}{(i + j + 1)(i + j + 2) \dotsm (i + j + 6)(i + j + 7)} \\
 &= \sum_{j = 0}^\infty \frac{1}{6} \left( \frac{1}{(i + j + 1)(i + j + 2) \dotsm (i + j + 6)} - \frac{1}{(i + j + 2) \dotsm (i + j + 6)(i + j + 7)} \right) \\ &= \frac{1}{6} \left( \frac{1}{(i + 1) \dotsm (i + 6)} - \frac{1}{(i + 2) \dotsm (i + 7)} \right) \\
 &\quad + \frac{1}{6} \left( \frac{1}{(i + 2) \dotsm (i + 7)} - \frac{1}{(i + 3) \dotsm (i + 8)} \right) \\ &\quad + \frac{1}{6} \left( \frac{1}{(i + 3) \dotsm (i + 8)} - \frac{1}{(i + 4) \dotsm (i + 9)} \right) +\dotsb \\
 &= \frac{1}{6 (i + 1)(i + 2) \dotsm (i + 5)(i + 6)}. \end{align}We can then write \begin{align} &\frac{1}{6 (i + 1)(i + 2) \dotsm (i + 5)(i + 6)} \\ &= \frac{1}{5} \cdot \frac{(i + 6) - (i + 1)}{6 (i + 1)(i + 2) \dotsm (i + 5)(i + 6)} \\
 &= \frac{1}{30} \left( \frac{1}{(i + 1)(i + 2)(i + 3)(i + 4)(i + 5)} - \frac{1}{(i + 2)(i + 3)(i + 4)(i + 5)(i + 6)} \right). \end{align}We obtain another telescoping sum: \begin{align} &\sum_{i = 0}^\infty \frac{1}{6 (i + 1)(i + 2) \dotsm (i + 5)(i + 6)} \\
 &= \sum_{i = 0}^\infty \frac{1}{30} \left( \frac{1}{(i + 1)(i + 2)(i + 3)(i + 4)(i + 5)} - \frac{1}{(i + 2)(i + 3)(i + 4)(i + 5)(i + 6)} \right) \\ &= \frac{1}{30} \left( \frac{1}{(1)(2)(3)(4)(5)} - \frac{1}{(2)(3)(4)(5)(6)} \right) \\
 &\quad + \frac{1}{30} \left( \frac{1}{(2)(3)(4)(5)(6)} - \frac{1}{(3)(4)(5)(6)(7)} \right) \\ &\quad + \frac{1}{30} \left( \frac{1}{(3)(4)(5)(6)(7)} - \frac{1}{(4)(5)(6)(7)(8)} \right) + \dotsb \\ &= \frac{1}{30} \cdot \frac{1}{(1)(2)(3)(4)(5)} = \boxed{\frac{1}{3600}}.
 \end{align}
 *)

theorem
fixes sum :: "nat \<Rightarrow> nat \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "\<forall>i j. sum i j = 1 / ((i + j + 1)*(i + j + 2)*(i + j + 3)*(i + j + 4)*(i + j + 5)*(i + j + 6)*(i + j + 7))"
and h1 : "\<forall>i. (\<Sum>j. sum i j) = 1 / 3600"
shows  "(\<Sum>i. \<Sum>j. sum i j) = 1 / 3600"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_9.informal problem: For all natural numbers $i$ and $j$, let $sum(i, j) = \frac{1}{(i + j + 1)(i + j + 2)(i + j + 3)(i + j + 4)(i + j + 5)(i + j + 6)(i + j + 7)}$. If the sum of $sum(i, j)$ over all $j$ for a fixed $i$ is always $\frac{1}{3600}$, then show that the double sum of $sum(i, j)$ over all $i$ and $j$ is also $\frac{1}{3600}$.
